title: Crystal Palace have a week to prove they can match Oliver Glasner’s ambition
description: The Austrian's lack of options was exposed in Sunday's 1-1 draw with Nottingham Forest - he needs proper backing
content:
Change has arrived at Crystal Palace. For the first time in over a decade, they have none of Wilfried Zaha, Michael Olise or Eberechi Eze to call upon. All of a sudden, there is no maverick creative attacking outlet on whom they can rely.

Before Sunday, since the last of that trio was signed in July 2021, Palace had played 11 games in which none of them featured. In those, they recorded just two wins, with four draws and five defeats. After the 1-1 home draw with Nottingham Forest, it is two victories in 12.

The difference now is that they are all going to be permanently absent.

The departures of Olise and Eze over the past year have raised almost £120million in transfer fees but, while the money is useful, finding adequate replacements for that type of star attacking player — the ones who can find space in the tightest of situations, dart past opponents with a mesmerising piece of skill, or score from anywhere with an exceptional finish — is not easy.

Without Eze against the low block of Norwegian visitors Fredrikstad in the first leg of a UEFA Conference League qualifying play-off on Thursday night, Palace struggled to break down their opposition as they dug out a 1-0 win. They created chances against Forest yesterday but, as time wore on and bodies began to tire, the only creative attacking substitute that manager Oliver Glasner could turn to was Romain Esse — who turned 20 earlier this summer, has one career Premier League start to his name and who he has conceded is not yet ready to play regularly at this level.

“Before I arrived, if I asked you: ‘Who are the most important players in Crystal Palace’s attack?’ (the answer would be) Eze and Olise,” Glasner had said in his pre-match media session. “Both are gone, and you (Palace) need to replace them.

“If we don’t do the right things now, then I’m worrying that it can go very quickly in the wrong direction in the Premier League. If I see what’s happening around us, (it is) even more (worrying).”

It all leaves Palace with just over a week, with the summer transfer window shutting next Monday evening, to give Glasner the tools he needs.

Palace’s general partners David Blitzer and Woody Johnson, the latter the club’s new addition at executive level, joined chairman Steve Parish in the Selhurst Park directors’ box yesterday. The matter of how much money will be committed to making signings in the coming days had to have been high on the agenda in their discussions.

Additions are clearly necessary. Glasner typically favours direct, diligent players over freer creative spirits, but he knows the balance is not there without a player such as Eze around. It is why his frustration at Palace’s relative lack of activity in the transfer market threatened to boil over after the game on Thursday, although he was more measured in his public pronouncements the next day and on Sunday.

Matt Hobbs, the club’s new sporting director, will soon arrive. Identifying talent has not been such an issue this summer, given much of the work was done before his predecessor Dougie Freedman left the club in March, and Parish has acknowledged that he has sought Freedman’s views on possible incomings. But there is still plenty of work to be done, and Hobbs should play a crucial role in that.

It is quite a contrast to Forest’s situation. When Palace tired in the second half yesterday, their opponents took advantage. Whereas Palace have just lost one of their best players in Eze, Forest not only kept hold of their most important one in Morgan Gibbs-White but could summon well over £100million of new signings from their bench as they sought a result in south London.

Among them was striker Igor Jesus — signed from Botafogo, part of Palace’s former general partner John Textor’s Eagle Football multi-club group — who rattled a late effort against the crossbar. Omari Hutchinson, another recent arrival, wasted a good chance in stoppage time. Forest were the stronger side in the second half, at least in part due to those they could bring on after trailing 1-0 at the break.

The home side had two goalkeepers and two academy players among their replacements, as well as the inexperienced Esse. Glasner says he wants to prioritise quality over quantity — although Palace require both — and this final week of the window could be the club’s last chance to make a compelling case for the 50-year-old Austrian to sign a new contract, with his current one expiring at the end of this season.

Demonstrate that they can meet his ambition and bring in talent as well as sufficient numbers and there will be hope of convincing their most successful manager to continue; fail to do so, and that task becomes much harder.

Palace posted an image of Zaha, Olise and Eze on their social media channels on Friday with the caption, ‘Don’t cry because it’s over, smile because it happened’. If Glasner is next in line to leave, that advice may be difficult to take.

It has been a long time since Palace have been presented with the dilemma of a successful manager who, despite being restricted by the lack of players at his disposal, is still bringing out the best with what he does have in his squad. But successful coaches also tend to be demanding ones, and if Palace hope to fend off the advances that will surely come for Glasner, a proven winner at multiple clubs, then they will need to deliver for him.

At least he was sounding more upbeat on Sunday evening.

“I’m pretty sure we will get the right (replacement) done,” Glasner said after the Forest game. “Because we have already found the right one.”

The next few days will be significant in determining how the new era at Selhurst is viewed and how successful it can become.
summary: Crystal Palace has not played without Wilfried Zaha, Michael Olise, or Eberechi Eze in over a decade, since their last contract was signed in July 2021, has left them without a creative attacking player. This makes the team no longer able to rely on these players. The departures of Olise and Eze over the past year have raised almost £120m in transfer fees, but finding adequate replacements for these types of star attacking players is not easy. Manager Oliver Glasner has expressed concern over the club's lack of transfer activity in the transfer market. The summer transfer window ends next Monday evening, giving the club just over a week to give Glasner the tools he needs. The club's new sporting director, Matt Hobbs, is expected to arrive soon.
shortSummary: Crystal Palace's season is entering a critical week as manager Oliver Glasner faces challenges with limited options, particularly due to the departure of key players like Zaha and Eze.

scraped_sources.text:
Few have left such an indelible mark on Crystal Palace as Eberechi Eze.
In years to come, the memory will endure of his trademark gliding runs beyond opposition defenders, an FA Cup-winning goal or, maybe above all else, that wonderfully infectious smile of his. Eze has departed for Arsenal, the club he supported in his youth and who released him at 13, but for whom his affection has never waned.
Advertisement
They are taking back a player offered his first real chance in senior football by Queens Park Rangers, but who developed significantly over five special years in south London. He became a star while at Selhurst Park, a Premier League game-changer and senior England international. And he was loved by all who came across him.
The fee for the 27-year-old, an initial £60million ($81.1m) with a further £7.5m of potential add-ons, should allow the club to kick on again. Eze was the poster boy for Palace’s rejigged recruitment strategy, targeting young talent with potential from the Championship and offering regular game-time at the higher level with a pathway onwards. Eze arrived for £16m. The club aimed to sell on at a significant profit.
His is the kind of success story then sporting director Dougie Freedman and chairman Steve Parish had targeted. The plan has come together.
Eze in full flight, with confidence, the love of the fanbase and his manager urging him on, is a spectacular watch. His mazy dribbles, the drop of the shoulder and his unique talent for escapology have illuminated so many Palace matches.
That appreciation came from afar at first, with Eze signed at the height of the pandemic. He took the step up to the top flight during Project Restart, but behind closed doors. The chance to see him live and in the flesh sustained the fanbase during that horrible time. The player himself delivered to food banks in Lewisham every week of that first season at the club. It was easy to love him on and off the pitch.
It took him no time to buy into the club’s community spirit. He has since launched his own charitable foundation in an attempt to revisit his roots and give back to the community which he believes gave him that early support he needed to bounce back from those rejections by Arsenal, Fulham, Millwall, Sunderland and Reading.
On the pitch, the player nurtured by QPR after those years in the wilderness found his feet quickly enough at Palace.
His unique talent helped give greater purpose and meaning to those sterile, soulless games. There was a mesmerising run from inside his own half beyond Sheffield United defenders, and then the most casual of finishes placed into the bottom corner from the edge of the box to seal a 2-0 win in January 2021. There have been many more special moments in the intervening years with crowds, restored to stadia, marvelling at his natural ability.
Advertisement
While it has not always been plain sailing and there have been periods of frustration, the mutual affection never waned.
The club rallied round after he ruptured an Achilles tendon in May 2021 — cruelly on the day he was named in England’s provisional Euro 2020 squad. That call-up had demonstrated the early impact he had made. The road back was hard and not without its bumps, and it was over two years before he made that senior debut for the national team, earning the first of 12 caps while a Palace player. That might have been a target after missing out in 2021, but it has always really been about enjoyment for Eze.
View this post on Instagram
“It feels like fun: running past players, playing passes, assisting and scoring,” he told The Athletic in 2023. “I just enjoy playing football and it’s like I’m at peace. That’s all it is for me. I guess that’s what allows me to do it.
“It is a fun place. I’m not thinking of anything; I’m just there doing it. There are not many other places where I feel like that.”
For a while, Palace boasted a squad blessed with their irrepressible homegrown star Wilfried Zaha, the prodigiously talented Michael Olise and Eze. The bromance he enjoyed with Olise, who departed a year ago for Bayern Munich, endeared him to the supporters even more despite occasional indifferent form. He always stepped up in the most important moments, when it mattered most. The FA Cup run proved that: Fulham, Aston Villa and Manchester City bear the scars of his brilliance.
It felt like goodbye on the Premier League opening weekend as Palace played out a goalless draw with Chelsea on Sunday. But his was an understated farewell, even if he lingered in front of the travelling support in the Shed End longer than he would normally.
It is unfortunate Palace supporters did not have the opportunity to say goodbye properly at Thursday night’s Conference League play-off against Fredrikstad, and that Eze’s first experience of UEFA competition will not now come at Selhurst Park as a reward for an outstanding five years’ work. He was at the ground, but not on the pitch.
Yet the warmth which emanates from within the club and the fanbase for him will remain.
He departs having helped transform the team. Few will resent him for his opportunity now to thrive elsewhere and take the next step in his career.
“I feel like if I’m given that licence, then I’m able to be free and create and that’s when I can make things happen,” he said in that 2023 interview.
While that was not always something afforded him at Palace, whether due to injury or ill-suited systems, he did always thrive when offered a stage. He made things happen. He made defenders look amateurish. He helped bring fans to their feet.
Advertisement
Those were his gifts. Now he is being rewarded in kind with a move to the club he loves more than any other.
One special moment at Wembley marked the high point. He took Palace to their first-ever major trophy. He helped make history. That will never be forgotten.
Eze’s greatest Palace moments
Palace 1-0 Manchester City, FA Cup final (May 17, 2025)
The ultimate contribution in the most important game Palace have ever played. Appropriate, given his outstanding run of form, dragging Palace out of a rut in the early stages of the quarter-final tie against Fulham with an outstanding individual goal, and scoring the opener with a thumping strike against Aston Villa in the semi-final.
But also because it was the culmination of everything for player and club: hard work, resilience and an attitude dedicated to never giving up in the face of adversity. This was his sixth goal in six games.
Eze on form, feeling free and loved, made a beeline for the middle of the penalty area in anticipation that Daniel Munoz would reach the ball first and cut it back to him. That is what happened and, with one swing of his boot, Eze had scored the goal which won the FA Cup for Palace.
Palace 3-0 Aston Villa, FA Cup semi-final (April 26, 2025)
With only a little backlift, Eze produced a moment of magic. Ismaila Sarr’s pass found him on the edge of the box, and he took a second and thrashed a shot past Emi Martinez in the blink of an eye. Eze stood there, knowing, believing, reminding everyone what he can do. It was the opening goal of the game and set Palace on their way at Wembley.
Palace 2-0 Sheffield United, Premier League (January 2, 2021)
The moment Eze properly introduced himself, even if it was behind closed doors. Although he beat only two Sheffield United players directly, it was the way he carried the ball so effortlessly, with such purpose and belief, only then to finish the move with such a casual swing of his boot without breaking stride. A wonderful moment.
Advertisement
Palace 5-2 West Ham United, Premier League (April 21, 2024)
Another example of his versatility and talent. Jean-Philippe Mateta’s shot was saved by Lukasz Fabianski only to bounce up into Eze’s path. He adjusted his body and thumped in a bicycle kick for the second of five Palace goals.
(Top photo: Eddie Keogh – The FA/The FA via Getty Images)

The English FA will investigate a banner displayed by Crystal Palace fans showing Nottingham Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis holding a gun to the head of midfielder Morgan Gibbs-White.
The banner was displayed in the Lower Holmesdale Stand, where the Holmesdale Fanatics supporters’ group sits, at Selhurst Park during Sunday’s Premier League game between the sides. It was not shown during Sky Sports’ UK broadcast of the match.
Advertisement
On the banner, Gibbs-White is shown with a speech bubble next to him reading: “Mr Marinakis is not involved in blackmail, match-fixing, drug trafficking or corruption!”
Marinakis has always strongly denied any wrongdoing in relation to these allegations.
As well as Gibbs-White, the banner also depicts Marinakis holding a briefcase overflowing with cash; what appears to be a UEFA delegate standing behind bags which read “correspondence” with the UEFA and Forest badges on; former Palace minority shareholder John Textor as a clown; and a ship with Marinakis’ name on — the Greek businessman is the founder and chairman of Capital Maritime & Trading Corp.
On the Palace website, in a statement which ends with “Published by The Football Association Premier League Limited”, the club say, “Banners must not contain foul language, be defamatory or contain political or offensive slogans and the club reserves the right to turn banners away if the content is felt to be offensive in any way.”
When contacted by The Athletic, the Premier League indicated the incident was a matter for the FA. Palace and Forest were approached for comment. The Holmesdale Fanatics declined to comment.
Ahead of the game, Palace said on social media that they “would like to remind supporters that acts of discrimination, including inappropriate chanting, violence and entering the field of play, will not be tolerated at Selhurst Park”.
Gibbs-White signed a new contract at Forest in late July, having been the subject of bids from Tottenham Hotspur and appearing set to have a medical at the north London club. The Athletic reported that Gibbs-White had a key 30-minute meeting with Marinakis before committing his future to Forest until 2028.
Tensions between Palace and Forest have grown over the summer after the former was demoted from the Europa League to the Conference League — with the latter promoted as a result — having been found to have breached UEFA’s multi-club ownership rules. UEFA’s decision to demote Palace was upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) earlier this month.
Advertisement
In 2021, a banner displayed at Selhurst Park by the Holmesdale Fanatics was the subject of a police investigation. That banner was on display when Newcastle United faced Palace, shortly after the north-east club’s takeover, which was largely funded by the Saudi Arabian Public Investment Fund (PIF). The banner took aim at the Premier League’s owners’ and directors’ test, and the Croydon Metropolitan Police said it had been reported as “offensive”.
Explaining the Palace-Forest tensions
In the aftermath of Palace’s demotion, their chairman Steve Parish did a round of media interviews in which he intimated that someone else had been behind the punishment.
“We’re led to believe that’s the issue,” said on The Rest Is Football podcast, when asked by host Gary Lineker if Forest had “played a part” in the process. “If there wasn’t someone who wanted to get in as a consequence, then there wouldn’t be a problem.”
This was in reference to a letter that Forest had written to UEFA about the issue, which they have always insisted was a matter of them simply seeking clarity about which competition they would be in this season, so they could plan accordingly. Forest also say the letter was sent when UEFA was already investigating Palace’s status amid a crackdown on these rules, which had already seen European football’s governing body kick Irish side Drogheda United and Slovakia’s DAC 1904 out of the Conference League for similar breaches.
Nevertheless, Forest’s owner Marinakis, along with former Palace minority shareholder John Textor — whose controlling stake in French side Lyon had been the trigger for Palace’s demotion — and UEFA, became the focus of Palace fans’ ire.
At their first three games of this season — the Community Shield at Wembley, the goalless Premier League draw away to Chelsea and the first leg at home against Fredrikstad — Palace fans displayed a banner with the words ‘UEFA MAFIA’ on a version of the body’s logo with a Euro symbol replacing the map of Europe, and also chanted “F*** UEFA, f*** John Textor, f*** Marinakis.” It’s clear who they blame for the situation, and it’s not anybody in the current Palace hierarchy.
(Top photo: Richard Pelham/Getty Images)

argos_summary: Crystal Palace are facing a crisis after the departures of key creative players Wilfried Zaha, Michael Olise and Eberechi Eze, leaving manager Oliver Glasner without a reliable attacking outlet. With the transfer window closing next Monday, the club’s new sporting director Matt Hobbs and board members are under pressure to secure replacements and demonstrate financial commitment, while Glasner warns that failure to do so could jeopardise his position. The club’s recent transfer strategy—selling young talent for profit—has been highlighted by Eze’s move to Arsenal, and fan unrest has manifested in controversial banners and chants. Overall, Palace must act quickly to rebuild their attack and maintain stability amid mounting expectations from owners, supporters and the Premier League.
